text:
- (SINGING) Swing
low, sweet chariot,
coming for to carry me home.

Swing low, sweet chariot,
coming for to carry me home.

- (SINGING) I
looked over Jordan,

and what did I see, coming
for to carry me home.
A band--

HARRY OTTLEY-BROOM:
It's a little bit 50-50,
'cause it's kind of patriotic.

People have been
singing it for a while.
It will be hard to stop back.

I can also see why some
people may find it,
like, offensive or whatever.

I'll just stick to-- probably
the other [inaudible], I think.
- (SINGING) Carry me home.

CASEY BOYD: Connotations come
from so many different angles
and different times.
So things change over the years.

So I would say that
what it represents

now is not the same thing
it represented back then.

And this is more
about a song that's

been sung to build spirits
and to build team spirits.

You know, people have
a different view of--

you know, when
they're singing it,

it's very evocative of
pulling people together.
- (SINGING) Sweet chariot.

TONY CRAWFORD: It's
just a great song.
It should be sung with gusto.

I mean, it's just
tradition, now, yeah?

So you need to just carry on.
Yeah.
- (SINGING) Home.
[applause]
